Really bad again, barely watchable

Ugh, probably the worst Friday the 13th.  It should have been called "Jason on a Boat", because the 67% of the movie is on a boat and not in New York, which was a huge let down!  I was anticipating seeing Jason stalk the city streets instead of the woods and was interested in seeing how that was played, but this movie didn't do that at all.  There wasn't really any deep characters (as usual) and most of the killing was pretty tame.  I did enjoy when Jason took Julius' head right off with one punch, that was pretty classic.

Why do I do this to myself? Do I just enjoy torture? Mind you, the first few Friday the 13th films were bad, but they weren't god-awful. Not at first. But they go so far downhill it's incredible. Five minutes into Friday The 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan, I knew I was in for a shit-storm.

Alright. The movie opens with as song about New York City, joined by a montage of the Big Apple, and followed shortly thereafter by a sex scene with two characters I don't know or care about. How does all this tie together? It doesn't. Do we ever hear about these two teenagers engaged in sex after they get killed by Jason? Of course not.

During this opening, we get a long, drawn out bit of exposition for the storyline of Jason Voorhees. This is interesting because I cannot help but wonder what sad sap will attempt to join the Friday The 13th storyline eight films in. As though there is any story at all.
Something else I really loved about this opening: the girl who just watched her boyfriend(?) get killed didn't even look scared while waiting for Jason come get her. It looked like they left the camera running and she was just staring off into space and decided to throw that shot into the movie. This is the type of film making and acting that we're in for, my dear readers. So bare with me. Oh, and there's still 90 minutes left of this movie.

For the rest of the movie, the audience is graced with the presence of actors who seem to be reading from cue cards standing on a boat that's on its way to NYC. Oh yes. Don't let the title confuse you; this movie is not set in Manhattan. It's set on a boat going to Manhattan. An easy mistake I am sure.

In addition to this, we have completely unique characters that people who have watched the series will have never seen before--like the old man who's catch phrase is "You're all doomed! Doomed!" Ah, yes, isn't the dialogue just riveting?

This reminds me of the most overused line in slasher film history:

"Stop screwing/playing/goofing/fooling around, guys!"

Every. Single. Slasher. Film. Has. This. Line.
ENOUGH! Think up some new lines!

Yes, my dear readers, Jason Takes Manhattan has the worst screenplay for a Friday movie yet--and that is saying something. For starters, I didn't even know how many people were on the boat. Not only that, I didn't know anyone's name. I did not bother to learn one person's name, that's how captivating and enriching these characters are. All these teenagers' range of character goes all the way from "only caring about sex" to "only caring about sex and drugs."

I guess I wasn't the only one who didn't know anyone on this boat, though. Jason is killing people for a good forty or fifty minutes before anyone even notices that anyone's missing. And remember that this isn't set in cabins out in the woods this time. Now there is no rhyme or reason for why the other characters wouldn't realize that their friends are completely missing and/or dead.

Just as in the last movie, it amazes me that a movie as plotless as a Friday The 13th sequel would bother to have subplots. This one does, and I couldn't care less about any of them. Plus, they wouldn't tell a story! This film could not tell a story! I kept getting so frustrated that this movie would be so much more concerned with trying to be "creepy" than to just tell one goddamn story! Oh, and I put the word "creepy" in quotes because what this movie tries to pass as creepiness comes off instead as just plain goofiness. That's the level that we have reached, my dear readers. By the way, the only decent plot thread that the story used was stolen--almost word for word--from an episode of M*A*S*H.

You know, calling a film "Jason Takes Manhattan" and having the opening montage show clips of NYC would lead me to believe that this movie might, I don't know, take place in NYC. But I'm so use to being let down by the Jason films by this point, I don't even know that I'm going to bother getting upset by this. Did this film have the budget to sink a ship but NOT the budget to take place in NYC? Not that I care, really. This whole movie sinks. The acting's bad, the story's bad, the dialogue is bad... It does have a little bit of the "dumb fun" element in it, but it's really being stretched here. This movie just plain sucks.

This is probably the worst movie in the Friday the 13th series, which is saying a lot. It seems like the studio hired a writer/director who had never seen these films. And by 1989 that's a little inexcusable. 

So the plot is about a group of high school graduates that are taking a cruise to New York for the graduation trip. Wish I went Crystal Lake High, I had to go to Hershey Park. Anyway Jason is brought back to life and decides to come along. Most of the teens are killed and then the surviving teens wonder around New York as Jason still pursues them. Eventually they end up in the NY sewer system where "toxic waste" is just casually dumped every night. This in turn "kills" Jason. THE END.

Here is my biggest problem with part 8. One of the characters in the film is afraid of water, because as a young girl her guardian pushed her into crystal lake to teach her how to swim. Once she's in the water a child 'Jason" is under the water trying to drown her. 
HERE'S THE PROBLEM, If you watch the other movies you'd know that "Jason" supposedly drowned in the 1950's. But actually he survived and lived in the woods. All the while his mom is killing counselors he's just kind of hanging back. And watching from the sidelines. Don't know why he did not come forward before hand but whatever. Anyway in parts 2-4 he is going on a rampage before Tommy Jarvis kills him in part 4. So we are lead to believe that before part 6 takes place Jason is in fact a real person. Not the supernatural zombie he becomes in part 6 and continues to be in part 7. So when in this film the little girl see's a young Jason trying to drown her it makes no sense because he shouldn't be this evil force. And when she was young Jason would have been in like his 20's. Anyway what I am trying to say is that in the illogical world of the Friday the 13th films, this one makes the least sense. 

(I might write a blog about how I am chronologically confused by this film series)

Part 8 is the beginning of the end for the Friday the 13th series and has one of the most misleading titles in cinema history. It's chock full of plot holes, terrible acting from the majority of the cast and some very poor kill scenes for a slasher film. It's obvious that film makers were running out of ideas and were struggling to think of anything new.

You could be forgiven for thinking that the plot line would focus on Jason stalking some teenagers on the streets of Manhattan, hence the title, sadly there is all of ten minutes screen time set in New York. Instead, we the majority of the plot takes place on a cruise liner containing a bunch of high school graduates from Crystal Lake celebrating with a trip to new York. Jason gets on board and begins his usual killing spree. This actually could have been an interesting plot line, a sort of Under Siege with a serial killer, sadly the execution was terrible.

Yet again Jason is brought back to life from the bottom of Crystal Lake by resurrection power of electricity. I will remember to get someone to zap me with 9000 volts of electricity when I die, problem solved. The first plot hole is a huge one, the main girl of the film supposedly saw Jason in Crystal Lake when she was a kid. Jason drowned in the 50's, it's now the 80's and she is still a teenager. Her time traveling skills were never explained. She is stalked by ghostly visions of Jason throughout the film, sometime he is deformed, sometimes isn't. Even though these scenes make no sense at least they try to evoke some kind of scary atmosphere. The kill scenes on the boat are original, a guitar and hot stones from a sauna are used, the problem is that they all happen off screen. There is almost zero gore, maybe the problems the previous film had with the MPAA were to blame for this.

Once we finally get to Manhattan the film picks up hugely. It's great fun seeing Jason stalk around New York with people ignoring him. It's fun and leaves you wondering why they didn't set the whole film there. We do have another problem though; somehow Jason seems to have developed the power of teleportation. One second he is on the streets, the next he is one the tenth story of a building with no explanation how he did it. The climax is very good and but again leaves you thinking what could have been.

Kane Hodder plays Jason very well and the makeup effects are top notch again. Sadly it's the misleading title, off screen deaths, poor script and poor acting that let the whole thing down.

Well, here it is. The final film of the original 8 parter of the Friday The 13th series, the film that for the 2nd time was meant to end it all (of course they didn't). The film certainly doesn't live up to its title well, being more like "Friday The 13th Part 8: Shipwrecked" and as much hate as this one gets for being one of the worst, I wasn't able to hate this film. I still hold a great dislike for A New Beginning as the worst of the original 8 films. The film, once again, makes no effort to establish many of the characters well... hell, a bunch die before we even know who the hell they are, who cares? That said, it was a mediocre effort and most of the film is on a boat, so by the time New York makes its appearance, its quite late. It feels much longer than it needs to be because of this time it takes, and you begin to wonder why the hell it took place on a boat to begin with. The deaths are fairly satisfying, a bit bloodier than the censored 7th film, but still very cut down. Dammit, I wish I could see this shit uncut! Anyhow, the kills are okay, and no matter how stupid you think the plot is, it's about as exciting as you could get for a series that's already running itself dry by this time. I wasn't put off with the ending being Jason's final moment. It may have been debatable for the time since it was thought to be the last film, but I know it isn't, so I know this won't be the end. The toxic waste is a cop-out, but oh well, I can do with it. The movie fails to live up to its name which is why its disappointing, and the film drags without much excitement at times, but for the most part I sort of enjoyed it, and its a good change of locations from thew usual cabins on the lakeside stuff.

Kane Hodder is supposedly one of the better Jasons as well but I have to say I think he's awful.  Anyway a poor entry and a weird nonsensical ending, all in all, not great.

There was a long time that i honestly thought that this was none of the worst movies ever made (maybe in some ways it kind of is) but sitting down and watching this almost ridiculously terrible film with likeminded people who i love very much the night before Halloween time this year it's insanely cheesy pleasures bubbled finally to the surface of all the toxic waste, much like the rest of the fridays, this is a party movie, a get drunk and watch with all your horror or casual movie fan mates and family up for a laugh type experience. Dont get me wrong this movie is truly fucking bad, in ways that sometimes skirt well past the line of "so bad it's good" (well, well past) but fuck me if it isnt great fun! first lets go through everything crappy about and wrong with this cheap ass, rip off of a flick. Firstly there's the title, Jason Takes Manhattan, it should have really been called Jason spends an hour and a bit on a boat killing assholes and wanders around some dark alleyways before spending the last ten or so minutes in actual, identifiable New York City. The big apple itself proved such an expensive shooting location that the screen time of the city is prattled down to nearly nothing, when the boar full of teens do actually arrive at the city harbor they spend about half an hour running around dark, dank alleys ways that could have been shot in fucking Skagness for all anyone knows, and then after about five mins in Times Square (were Jason very lamely scares off some switchblade wielding, boombox playing 80's punks by pulling up his mask) we then end up in dreary subway tunnels that, once again, could have been and most definitely were filmed somewhere else( i think every inch of NY footage they shot is in this movie, just look at the opening credits bit) The other weird fucking thing is that Camp Crystal Lake is now Camp Ocean Mouth really, as the lake has turned into a huge, almost edge-less horizon surrounded by massive snow peaked mountains in the distance (where ever they shot this is actually quite stunning i must admit) and it connects to the ocean, "hmm, okay then"....and we have a almost ocean liner sized ship full of graduating teens setting sail from a huge dockland that has also materialized. Jason tags along of course, after hilarious resurrection by electric volts from a falty underwater power cable ( why did no one go in and retrieve his body?) Jason, now a waterlogged, gooey corpse, grabs onto the anchor and joins the party. He's certainly welcome to the roster of teen meat to butcher, horrible, awful characters all, even by the Friday The 13th series low standard of actual likable human beings. The kills are sort of all over the place in this one too, being one of the series most obvious and severe victims of the MPAA, sometimes you get no pay off to a kill scene build up, like for instance the nasty cokehead bitch, i needed to see her get hers, thats the whole point of her fucking existence in this movie, it's like sex without the climax. But on the other hand when u do actually see the kills they are often so outlandish and ridiculous (the boxing death is especially cartoonish) that you just have to cheer and laugh, plus there are SO many!! (this has the highest single body count of the franchise, Jason really dose kill a fuckload of unlikable folks in this film!) another thing worth pointing out is the outright dive into Nightmare On Elm Street type supernatural sequences and imagery, with the final girls weird, oddly executed connection to Jason and her bizzare visitations of a the undead killing machine in his drowned child form as a ghostly spectre, there.s some groovy effects (the mirror bit) but it's all very half baked and vague, even baffling, like Jason reverting to child form after being hit by an apparently rejuvenating tidal wave of toxic waste, the actual fuck? but like i said, watch it with the right people, in the right atmosphere and knowing what you can and should be looking get out of it (an amazingly trashy, bad, cheesy, poorly acted, cheap, tacky pisstake of a film, with much 80's amp value) and you must be drunk, like really drunk.

Re-watching this was not a pleasant experience. I really had to force myself to watch it and once I finally did it was almost painful to make myself sit through the entire thing. Continuity is probably the film's biggest flaw. When we see young Jason drown, he looks like a normal little boy. Whenever Rennie sees him, however, he suddenly looks like he has down syndrome and like somebody beat him with a 2x4 made from every ugly branch they could get a hold of. On top of that, he pretty much has a different appearance every time Rennie sees him. Then there's the whole Crystal Lake leading into the ocean thing and the ending. Heavens, the ending is just a clusterfuck of retardism. The script isn't so hot either. Julius is probably the best example. After Wayne asks him what weapon he's going to take after they realize Jason is on the ship, Julius replies, "Nothing," then pauses for a moment before following with, "...but this gun." The kills were also lacking. Jason takes a guitar to a girl's head and throws a guy onto an antenna. That's about as inventive as we get this time around. The one enjoyable factor of the film is Kane Hodder as Jason. The scene in Times Square is probably the highlight of the film. It's disappointing that the last film with "Friday the 13th" in the title is so bad.

The Paramount years for the series ends with a whimper with this low budget waste of time. An intriguing premise is never realized because the budget would not allow for more than one night of filming in NY. The rest of the film was shot in Toronto. The cast is kept minimal as well. The entire crew of a cruise ship consists of the captain, a first mate and  one crazy crewman who spends most of his time predicting doom. Plus the school celebrating the graduation is about ten students strong including two chaperons and a dog.  Ironically the film is the longest in the series.

The weakest entry in the franchise, with a very inappropriate title and some bad acting. This should have been titled "Jason on a ship" because that's where Jason spent the majority of the film, while Manhattan was just the place for the slow-moving climax. And the fistfight with Jason on the rooftop is a very dumb way to solidify Jason's power, yes, he is very strong, we have already seen that in its long-spanning sequels, so why show him punching a man so strong that it decapitated him? Even Jason's face when unmasked looked like a cartoon character, and him turning into a kid again was nonsensical. And finally, putting a happy ending in a "Friday the 13th" film with a cheesy song is not applicable, because end sequences like that belongs to films like "Commando" and other early Schwarzenegger macho-actioners. The good thing with this film is its atmosphere, recreating New York's underbelly wonderfully, but other than that, this one's very weak.

Watching this flick, I believe writer and director Rob Hedden set out to destroy the franchise. If I knew this was going to be a stinker, I would have traveled back in time and force him to change the location to New Jersey. Jason Takes New Jersey with a scene involving Jason killing a man by pushing him into a bathtub filled with water, ha ha. So, this is just water! It's not just water. It's New Jersey water! Oh no! Aghhhhh! The guy dissolves in the New Jersey water along with a New Jersey death style. Kidding. The film's problem also revolves around the fact that the film takes much of in the boat; therefore, the flick is really Jason Terrorizes Love Boat. Heck, Manhattan looks a lot like Vancourer. The fans and critics of the series knew this by heart, so it leads to a poor performance at the box office. The film ranks as one of the lowest in profits with a 5 million dollar budget. Gee, I am not surprised. The characters are pretty much the same as the play the stereotype they're to play along with annoying performances and predictable outcomes. The film is wretched upon the weak acting throughout the entire film as characters will shout or say a line, but leave an awkward pause in the middle. Kane Hodder (Jason Voorhees) is nearly the only one who can act because he does not deliver a line throughout the film. Even Peter Richman does a terrible job, you think cause of his age he would do a decent job, but he stinks as well. A perfect example of this is Halloween- the Curse of Michael Myers and that flick was incompetent, but Donald Pleascene brought some light to the dying film with his performance. Here we have nearly nothing to look forward in the characters. The cockeyed geezer annoyed me, so did the kid playing Jason Voorhees. One scene, we see the boy with a deformed right eye, but then he appears with a deformed left eye. I got annoyed how we get a fake and poorly acted drowning scene with him. Also, I was pretty unsurprised with the repressed memory Rennie had as it is connected to Jason. I didn't care much for the gore or death scenes except for the death of Charles (we knew it was going to happen). I was ready to write it off, but a funny thing happen. The scenes of supposedly Manhattan and actual Manhattan came in and saved the film barely to avoid 1. I love a scene where one of the characters decides to fight Jason with a boxing technique. I noticed 2 comical things: 1. Julius was an amateur 2. Those punches were pi*sing Jason. I applauded the scene afterwards.The scenes have suspense in them as Jason pursues his target while taking New Yorkers as the mosquitoes that can't be bothered with. We get a great and stupid gag with a boom box scene as these "punks" are listening to rap. There is a fiasco scene where a waitress does a sleazy job at the emergency the kids ask her. This was all pretty fun to watch although I couldn't help noticed that the entire film was a wasted opportunity. Oh and on a special note, I love the logical errors surrounding the film as we see character getting wet from the ocean, but found completely dried in the next scene. As for writer and director Rob Hedden, I am very sure he had a vision, but he wasn√¢(TM)t right for the job. Although it√¢(TM)s not his fault and we shouldn√¢(TM)t hunt him down, I call him to fiction world where a fate like Charles√¢(TM)s characters can take place. The music was all wrong too. Where's Agnostic Front when you need them?

Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan
written and directed by Rob Hedden
based on characters created by Victor Miller
starring Kane Hodder, Jensen Daggett, Barbara Bingham, Peter Mark Richman, Saffron Henderson, Martin Cummins, Vincent Craig Dupree, Sharlene Martin

First of all, Jason doesn¬ít exactly ¬ìtake¬î Manhattan.  Two thirds of the way through the picture he does manage to visit there and continue in his delightful occupation, but it hardly constitutes full-blown mayhem which the title certainly promises.  What we have is a boatload of highschool seniors who are heading off to New York for their graduation.  As the film opens, a naughty couple are having sex aboard a boat.  They drop anchor and it inadvertently hits a powerline which awakens Jason yet again.  He manages to get on the pleasure cruise ship and subsequently fulfils his tender oath and begins slaughtering the unsuspecting ciphers one at a time.

This film adds an element that hasn¬ít been as pronounced in earlier installments in the series.  Jason¬ís victims bleat and plea for their lives more in this one and it adds a scintillating element to the story.  Best of all is a scene with the prissy and demonstrably conniving Tamara Mason is taking a shower and Jason comes in to seduce her.  While romance is thwarted and he ends up stabbing her with a shard from a broken mirror.  She cowers, whines, and otherwise puts on a pretty decent show before her unceremonious demise at the hands of her would be suitor.

Jason¬ís kills are not very imaginative here and the film definitely lacks style points as the dull, burdensome killings continue unabated.  If only there was a single character worth getting thrilled over than these films would be more vital than they are.  Instead, we are left with characters who, as has almost always been the case, lack a discernible personality that elevates them above the typical kill victim.  Actually, there was a promising character early in the film but Jason spears him within the first ten minutes.  His performance suggests something more than what is generally to be expected in these films.

In this film a girl named Rennie Wickham (Daggett) is taking the cruise against the wishes of her Uncle Charles McCulloch (Richman), the group¬ís chaperone.  She is haunted throughout the entire film by images of a young Jason who we learn apparently tried to pull her down after Uncle Charles pushed he off the dock intending to teach her how to swim.  She sees him everywhere and it truly twists her melon to the point that she can hardly tell what is real and what is imaginary at some point.  Rennie is a meek girl who is shy and the complete opposite of girls like Tamara, the prom queen who also enjoys a bit of nose candy now and again. Rennie is protected somewhat by Miss Colleen Van Deusen (Bingham), another chaperone who is constantly at odds with Uncle Charles.

One imagines terrific excitement once Jason finally lands in Manhattan but the result is pretty much a downer.  Yes, he takes care of a couple of junkie thugs, a cop, a bouncer at a bar, and several members of our merry crew who escaped when the ship caught on fire.  But he has so much opportunity to run wild in the streets cleaning up the sewage at every opportunity.  Instead, his focus remains strictly on the last two survivors and he chases them on a subway, through Times Square, and into the sewers.  Again, so many chances are not taken and the end is not particularly satisfying.  

There is something rather odd about watching Jason perform basic human tasks such as shutting a storage hatch.  Somehow the action is more pronounced, more deliberate, and not without its grace.  It shows an elegance about Jason which he mostly attempts to hide when he¬ís off enjoying the sights and hacking up his chosen ones.  This film shows that Jason has a very focused mind and is not distracted easily by what is taking place around him.  He chases his victims with a strong sense of purpose and never gives up on them.  He knows what he wants and how to get it.  So very few nowadays can say the same thing which makes Jason into a character worth admiring on a certain level.  He¬ís very good at what he does although he does seem to run into some trouble now and again.  No matter, there¬ís always lightning or power surges or a girl¬ís telekinesis to help him out of a tight scrape.

Overall, this film does nothing particularly novel and lacks some of the urgency that has made earlier films in the series more dynamic.  The deaths are rudimentary and the film simply does not live up to its title.  Ultimately, there is little character development which is nothing particularly new for the franchise.  Jason¬ís killing spree seems truncated and could have enveloped so much more if that plot line were pursued.

The reason i love these films so much isnt for the great storylines, or the oscar worthy acting. Its purely for the kills and Jason is on great form, hacking his way through a boatload of students on there way to New York. Theres an air of 80s cheese about this entry, especially in the soundtrack (which is all poodle rock) and the especially funny new york gang members. Its a pretty refreshing idea to take Jason out of Crystal Lake and drop him into Manhatten. There are some pretty good kills to be had and its another enjoyable entry in the Friday the 13th series.
